   (a)   The City Manager is hereby authorized to provide all employees of the
City with a copy of the Personnel Policies and Procedures Manual and to
administer all provisions of the Manual.
   (b)   The City Manager is further authorized to revise and update the Manual
as needed without further action by the Council and to provide the Council with
copies of such revisions and updates as they occur. (Ord. 2010-38. Passed 6-22-
10.)
123.06 GUIDELINES FOR GRANTS AND IN-KIND SUPPORT.
   (a)   Grant Objectives and Requirements.
      (1)   Proposals must be designed to improve the quality of life for the
citizens, businesses, and/or families of the City.
      (2)   Proposals should describe the need being met, and how it would
provide measureable impacts to the City.
      (3)   Applying organization must provide proof of non-profit status which
would qualify it as such under the Internal Revenue Code.
      (4)   Financial grant requests for the following calendar year must be
submitted completely to the Office of the City Manager no later than September
15th. To the extent possible, applicants for grants less than five thousand
dollars ($5,000) should be able to apply on a time frame as short as ninety
(90) days.
      (5)   Typical forms of City support may include, but not be limited to:
         A.   Grants for special capital projects,
         B.   Grants for programming that provides direct services to citizens,
businesses, and/or families of the City,
         C.   Grants for the purchase of materials like lumber, paint and other
such items,
         D   Use of City property including public parks or other City of
Loveland property.
         E.   The use of City employees such as police, fire and public works
employees at special events,
         F.   City services such as electricity, water, or other materials
supportive of an event or organization,
         G.   Waiver of City fees.
      (6)   Grants or in-kind support shall not be given to:
         A.   Projects that do not benefit the citizens, families, and/or
businesses of Loveland,
         B.   An individual,
         C.   Fund on-going operating expenses,
         D.   Fund debt-reductions, deficits from prior periods or other prior
period liabilities,
         E.   Fund political projects, sabbatical leaves or scholarly research,
         F.   Fund venture capital for competitive profit-making activities,
         G.   Fund scholarships directly, and
         H.   Religious organizations for religious purposes. (Religious
organizations may receive grants or in-kind support for non-religious purposes,
however).
   (b)   Proposal Checklist:
      (1)   Submit an original and three (3) copies (typed) of the grant
application to the City Manager using the form attached, including:
         A.   Application Cover Sheet.
         B.   Project Narrative (limit: one page, 12 point font or larger).
         C.    Organizational History (limit: one page, 12 point font or
larger).
         D.   Board minutes authorizing the organization's filing an
application.
         E.   A list of the members of the board of directors and current
officers including their addresses, phone number and e-mail addresses.
         F.   Organization's by-laws,
         G.   Policies for dealing with potential conflicts of interest,
whistle-blower and document retention and destruction.
         H.   Certificate of insurance (and if requested by the City, said
certificate shall name the City of Loveland as an additional insured).
         I.   Last two (2) years annual operating statements and projected
operating statement for grant year and capital budget to the extent available.
         J.   Audited financial statement for the most recently completed
fiscal year to the extent available
         K.   Project budget of proposed sources of funds and expenses.
      (2)   If any of the above-listed documents are unchanged or not amended
from the organization's immediately prior year application, an officer of the
organization may simply state as such on the application sheet and the document
may be omitted. The City of Loveland reserves the right to request unchanged
supporting materials for any reason.
      (3)   The City may, in its sole discretion, request additional
information and documentation to make its decision to provide support to any
organization.
   (c)   Application Cover Sheet.

125.01 DIVISION OF TAXATION.
   The Division of Taxation shall be charged with the administration of the
income tax laws of the City, under the direction of the Director of Finance.
The Director of Finance shall prescribe the form and methods of accounts and
reports for this division, as well as the forms for taxpayers’ returns and
declarations, and shall be charged with the internal examination and audit of
all such accounts and shall exhibit accurate records showing the amount
received from each taxpayer, and the date of the receipt. The Director of
Finance shall also make written report to Council annually of all monies
collected under the City income tax during the preceding year. Any or all of
the duties of the Director of Finance may be delegated, by the City Manager, to
the Assistant Finance Director or to any other position deemed appropriate.
(Ord. 2021-65. Passed 7-14-21.)
125.02 PUBLIC FUNDS INVESTMENT; TREASURY INVESTMENT BOARD; CAPITAL IMPROVEMENT
FUND.
   (a)   It is the policy of the City to invest public funds in a manner which
will provide the highest return with the maximum security, while meeting the
daily cash flow demands of the City, and conforming to (1) the Ohio Revised
Code governing such investments, except that investments will mature within
five (5) years from the date of purchase, and (2) the guidelines listed below
as identified by the Government Finance Officers Association and the Municipal
Treasurers Association, to wit:
      (1)   Safety. Safety of principal is the foremost objective of the
investment program. Investments of the City shall be undertaken in a manner
that seeks to ensure preservation of capital in the overall portfolio.
      (2)   Liquidity. The investment portfolio will remain sufficiently liquid
to enable the City to meet all operating requirements which might be reasonably
anticipated.
      (3)   Return on investment. The investment portfolio shall be designed
with the objective of attaining market rate of return throughout budgetary and
economic cycles, taking into account the City's risk constraints and cash flow
characteristics.
   (b)   The City Manager, the Finance Director and Chairman of the Finance
Committee constitute a Treasury Investment Board of the City, with full power
to determine monies available for investment, and to select and manage such
investments. The Finance Director is authorized to administer day-to-day
operations, maintain required documentation and provide annual Treasury report.
   (c)   The authorized investment options include:
      (1)   Depository accounts payable or withdrawable on demand, including
negotiable order of withdrawal accounts and sweep type account structures at
designated depositories.
      (2)   The "State Treasury Assets Reserve of Ohio" (S.T.A.R. Ohio), an
investment pool managed by the Treasurer of the State of Ohio.
         (Ord. 1999-23. Passed 5-25-99.)
      (3)   Certificates of deposit with any national savings and loan or
national bank located in the State of Ohio with FDIC or FSLIC coverage and
which qualify as eligible financial institutions under Ohio R.C. Chapter 135.
         (Ord. 2008-44. Passed 6-10-08.)
      (4)   U.S. Treasury Bills, Notes, and Bonds.
      (5)   Various federal agency securities, including issues of Federal
National Mortgage Assn. (FNMA), Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. (FHLMC),
Federal Home Loan Bank (FHLB), Federal Farm Credit Bank (FFCB), Student Loan
Marketing Assn. (SLMA), Government National Mortgage Assn. (GNMA), and other
agencies or instrumentalities of the United States. Eligible investments also
include any securities that may be "called" [by the issuer] prior to the final
maturity date. Any eligible investment may be purchased at a premium or a
discount. All federal agency securities shall be direct issuances of federal
government agencies or instrumentalities.
         (Ord. 1999-23. Passed 5-25-99.)
      (6)   Investment advisory services. The Treasury Investment Board of the
City is hereby authorized to obtain investment advisory services to enhance the
yield on investments provided all investments be consistent with the investment
policies of the City of Loveland and the laws governing municipal investment in
the State of Ohio. City Council shall have the sole right to approve a contract
with an investment advisory firm.
         (Ord. 2009-21. Passed 3-10-09.)
   (d)   A special projects capital improvement fund is established for the
receipt of all interest earned on all "funds" maintained by the City. Other
sources of revenue may also be receipted to this fund at the direction of City
Council, provided that such receipting does not violate any provision of law.
(Ord. 1999-23. Passed 5-25-99.)
125.03 BOND FOR THE DIRECTOR OF FINANCE.
   The City Council does hereby fix the bond for the Finance Director to be in
the amount of fifty thousand dollars ($50,000). Said bond shall be provided for
the faithful performance of duties and the premiums shall be paid by the City
(Ord. 1993-63. Passed 9-28-93.)
125.04 INCOME TAX ADMINISTRATOR.
   The Director of Finance shall serve as the Income Tax Administrator.
(Ord. 2021-65. Passed 7-14-21.)
125.05 DEBT POLICY.
   The City Council does hereby establish the following debt policy:
   (a)   The City will not use debt to fund current operations, reserves or
contingencies.
   (b)   The City will confine long-term borrowing to long-term capital
improvements for projects that cannot be financed from current revenues.
   (c)   The City will use special assessment or other self-supporting debt
instead of general obligation bonds whenever possible.
      (Ord. 1997-15. Passed 3-11-97.)
   (d)   When the City finances capital projects by issuing bonds, it will pay
back the bonds within a period not to exceed the expected useful life of the
project. The maximum period will not exceed twenty years, except for the
issuance of bonds for the construction of the City of Loveland YMCA, which bond
shall not exceed twenty- eight years.
(Ord. 2007-62. Passed 8-28-07.)
   (e)   The City will seek level or declining debt repayment schedules and
will avoid issuing debt that provides for balloon principal payments reserved
at the end of the term issue.
   (f)   The City will avoid variable rate debt due to the potential volatility
of such instruments.
   (g)   Total long-term general obligation debt will not exceed 3% of the
assessed valuation of taxable property, excluding self-supported debt.
   (h)   Total debt service for long-term general obligation debt, excluding
self-supporting debt, will not exceed ten percent (10%) of total annual
unrestricted governmental revenue. The formula for unrestricted governmental
revenue is General Fund revenues (less grants, transfers and estate tax), Net
Income Tax Collections (less refunds) and Interest Income.
      (Ord. 1997-15. Passed 3-11-97.)
125.06 ADMINISTRATIVE ASSISTANT.
   Council approves the establishment of the position of Assistant Finance
Director who shall perform such duties and functions as required by the job
description as approved by the City Manager. (Ord. 2019-80. Passed 9-10-19.) 
125.07 AUTHORIZED SIGNATORIES.
   The City of Loveland does hereby establish the following signatory policy:
   (a)   The Director of Finance, City Manager, Assistant Finance Director, and
Clerk of Council are authorized to serve as Signatories for all City accounts.
To open or close City bank accounts shall require two authorized signatories.
      (Ord. 2019-80. Passed 9-10-19.)
   (b)   City issued disbursements of less than one thousand dollars ($1,000)
or payroll checks shall require the City Manager’s signature only, or one of
the three other authorized signatories in the City Manager’s absence.
   (c)   City issued disbursements in excess of one thousand dollars ($1,000)
shall require two authorized signatories.
   (d)   Wire transfer of City funds shall require two authorized signatories.
   (e)   Accounts opened for investment of excess City funds shall require two
authorized signatories and direction from the City’s investment advisory board.
      (Ord. 2012-24. Passed 3-27-12.)

127.01 LEGAL OPINIONS.
   The City Solicitor shall, within a reasonable time, reply orally or in
writing to an inquiry of an officer of the City who entertains doubts
concerning the law in any matter before him in his official capacity, which
inquiry clearly states in writing the question on which the opinion is desired.
As used in this section, the term “officer” is limited to the City Manager, the
Finance Director, the Chief of Police, the Building Inspector, the City
Engineer, the Council acting by majority vote at a quorum at any regular or
special Council meeting, and each board and commission provided for by the
Charter or Codified Ordinances of the City, acting by majority vote of a quorum
of such board or commission at a regular or special meeting of such board or
commission. However, in any case in which the City Solicitor shall determine
that the opinion requested may be given orally, and without a significant
expenditure of time for research and analysis, the request for such opinion
shall not require a majority vote of the Council, or board of commission as
hereinbefore provided. Nothing herein provided shall prohibit the City
Solicitor from rendering an opinion or providing legal advice, without request
or inquiry, when he determines that such an opinion or advice is required for
the lawful conduct of City affairs.
(1980 Code 35.02)

129.02 GENERAL RESPONSIBILITY OF DEPARTMENT AND DIVISION HEADS.
   (a)   Each department and division head shall perform all duties required of
his office by Charter, by ordinance, or other laws, and he shall perform other
duties not in conflict therewith as may be assigned by the City Manager.
   (b)   All department heads shall:
      (1)    Be immediately responsible to the City Manager for the effective
administration of their departments and all activities assigned thereto;
      (2)    Keep informed as to the latest practices in their particular field
and shall inaugurate, with the approval of the City Manager, such new practices
as appear to be of benefit to the service and to the public;
      (3)    Submit reports of the activities of their departments when
requested by the City Manager;
.       (4)    Establish and maintain a system of records and reports in
sufficient detail to furnish all information necessary for proper control of
departmental activities and to form a basis for the reports required by the
City Manager. (Ord. 1980-6. Passed 1-22-80.)

131.01 POLICE DIVISION; COMPOSITION AND CONTROL.
   The Police Department shall be composed of a Chief of Police, appointed by
the City Manager, and such other officers and personnel as may be authorized by
Council.
(Ord. 2023-33. Passed 3-23-23.)
131.02 ORIGINAL APPOINTMENT.
   Any person twenty-one years of age or older may receive an original
appointment to the Police Department providing that he or she meets the
physical requirements necessary to perform the duties of a policeman or
policewoman as established by the Civil Service Commission.
(Ord. 1971-19. Passed 5-18-71; Ord. 1980-6. Passed 1-22-80.)
131.03 CHIEF OF POLICE.
   The Chief of Police shall have exclusive control of the stationing and
transferring of all patrolmen and other officers and employees in the Police
Division, under such general rules and regulations as the Director of Safety
prescribes.
(Ord. 1980-6. Passed 1-22-80.)
131.04 FIRE DIVISION; COMPOSITION AND CONTROL.
   The Fire Division shall be composed of a Chief, appointed by the City
Manager, and such other officers, volunteer firefighters, and employees as
provided by ordinance. The Director of Safety shall have the exclusive
management and control over such other secretaries, clerks, and employees as
are provided by ordinance or resolution of the Council. Neither this section
nor any section of this Code or the Ohio Revised Code requires, or shall be
construed to require, that the Fire Chief be a resident of the City.
(Ord. 1980-6. Passed 1-22-80.)
131.05 CHIEF OF FIRE DIVISION.
   If and when the City establishes its own Fire Division, the Chief of the
Fire Division shall have exclusive control of the stationing and transferring
of all firefighters and other officers and employees in the Division under such
general rules and regulations as the Director of Safety prescribes. (Ord. 1980-
6. Passed 1-22-80.)
131.06 EMERGENCY PATROLMEN AND FIREFIGHTERS.
   In case of riot or other like emergency, the City Manager may appoint
additional patrolmen and officers for temporary service in the Police Division,
or firefighters and officers for temporary service in the Fire Division, who
need not be in the classified list of such division. Such additional persons
shall be employed only for the time during which the emergency exists.
(Ord. 1980-6. Passed 1-22-80.)
131.07 GENERAL DUTIES OF POLICE AND FIRE DIVISIONS.
   (a)   The Police Force of the City shall preserve the peace, protect persons
and property, and obey and enforce all ordinances of the legislative authority
thereof and all criminal laws of the state and the United States.
   (b)   The Fire Division shall protect the lives and property of all people
in case of fire.
   (c)   Both the Police and Fire Divisions shall perform such other duties as
are provided by ordinance or as may be ordered by the Director of Safety.
(Ord. 1980-6. Passed 1-22-80.)
131.08 DIVISION OF BUILDING INSPECTION AND ZONING ADMINISTRATION.
   The Division of Building Inspection and Zoning Administration shall be
composed of a Building Official, Building Inspector(s), Zoning Administrator,
Property Maintenance Code Official and Permit Clerk as appointed by the City
Manager, and such other number of deputy inspectors and other employees as may
be provided by ordinance of Council. The division staff shall enforce the
Building Code, the Property Maintenance Code, the Zoning Code, and such other
codes as may be assigned for enforcement to this division by the City Manager.
The division is also responsible for the process of plan review, permitting,
inspections, zoning to ensure proper land development and promote high-quality
design standards through the enforcement of state and local building and zoning
codes.
(Ord. 2021-65. Passed 7-14-21.)
131.09 JURISDICTION OUTSIDE THE CITY.
   All police and sanitary regulations contained within the ordinances and the
Codified Ordinances of the City, and all additions and amendments thereto
enacted after the effective date of this section, are declared to be effective
within all lands owned by the City outside the corporate limits of the City.
The Police Department of the City is empowered to enforce such regulations
within such lands the same as if such lands were located within the municipal
corporation limits of the City. (Ord. 1978-30. Passed 6-27-78.)

133.01 DEPARTMENT OF SERVICE; DIRECTOR OF SERVICE.
   (a)   The Department of Service shall have the custody, care and maintenance
of the public buildings, grounds, streets, storm sewers and municipal utilities
owned by the City. The administrative head of this department shall be known as
the Public Works Superintendent and such position shall be filled by the City
Manager and shall be responsible for managing and supervising all public works
and undertakings of the City as set forth in subsection (b) hereof.
   (b)   The Public Works Superintendent shall manage and supervise all public
works and undertakings of the City except as otherwise provided by the Charter
or state law. The superintendent shall supervise the improvements and repair of
parks, streets, avenues, alleys, lands, lanes, squares, bridges, sidewalks,
storm sewers, drains, ditches, culverts, streams and watercourses, the
lighting, sprinkling, and cleaning of public places, and the construction of
public works, except those having reference to the Department of Safety or as
otherwise provided by the Charter or state law. The Public Works Superintendent
shall manage the municipal water works, and shall make and preserve surveys,
maps, plans, drawings, and estimates of and for the City. They shall supervise
the construction and have charge of the maintenance of public buildings and
other property of the City. They shall perform such other duties as may be
assigned by ordinance of the City or as directed by the City Manager.
(Ord. 2021-65. Passed 7-14-21.)
133.02 DIVISION OF WASTEWATER TREATMENT; WASTEWATER TREATMENT SUPERINTENDENT.
[RESERVED]
(Ord. 2021-65. Passed 7-14-21.)
133.03 DIVISION OF WATER; WATERWORKS SUPERINTENDENT.
   The Division of Water shall be administered by the Waterworks Superintendent
who shall be appointed by the City Manager, who shall be responsible to the
Director of Service for all work having to do with water treatment, operation,
maintenance of all pumping equipment, reservoirs, and the water distribution
system. He shall exercise supervision over all operators and employees and
assume other duties as may be assigned by ordinance or as directed by the
Director of Service. (Ord. 1980-6. Passed 1-22-80.)

135.01 DEPARTMENT OF RECREATION; RECREATION DIRECTOR.
   The Department of Recreation shall be administered by the Recreation
Director who shall be appointed by the City Manager with the approval of
Council. The Recreation Director shall perform such functions and duties as may
be assigned by ordinance, by the Recreation Commission, or by the City Manager.
(Ord. 1980-6. Passed 1-22-80.)
                                                                                                                           
CHAPTER 139
Boards and Commissions Generally
139.01   Model rules.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Creation and abolishment of offices - see CHTR.
9.01
Appointment and removal - see CHTR.

139.01 MODEL RULES.
   (a)   Adoption by Reference. As of the effective date of this section, each
committee, commission, and board of the City shall be governed by the
provisions of the Model Committee Rules which are attached to Ordinance 1992-
1 and incorporated herein by reference, except where a provision of such Model
Rules conflicts with a specific provision of the Charter, the Codified
Ordinances and/or the action of Council which established such committee,
commission, or board.
   (b)   Amendments. The Model Rules may be amended to address the individual
needs and mission statements of each such committee, commission or board. Such
amendment may be made upon the sole initiative of Council or upon the
recommendation, by an appropriate resolution, of a majority of the voting
members of a particular committee, commission, or board at a scheduled meeting
thereof and with the approval by motion of such recommendation by Council.
   (c)   Noncompliance; No Powers or Duties Conferred. Nothing herein shall be
construed to give raise to an attack upon the validity of any action taken by
any committee, commission, or board of the City merely by reason of
noncompliance with the Model Rules. Nor shall the Model Rules confer upon any
such committee, commission, or board any powers or duties not authorized by the
Charter, Codified Ordinances, and/or the action of Council which established
such committee, commission, or board.
   (d)   Notification. The Clerk of Council shall officially transmit a copy of
this section to the chairperson of each of the City's committees, commissions,
and boards.
(Ord. 1992-1. Passed 1-14-92.)
                                                                                                                              
CHAPTER 141
Records Commission

CROSS REFERENCES

141.01 ESTABLISHED; MEMBERS; CHAIRMAN.
   (a)   Council hereby approves the establishment of a City Records Commission
which shall be made up of the following officials of the City:
      (1)   City Manager;
      (2)   Director of Finance;
      (3)   City Solicitor; and
      (4)   Mayor or the Mayor's appointed representative from City Council.
   (b)   The City Manager shall serve as chairman of the Records Commission and
the City Solicitor shall serve as Secretary.
(Ord. 1991-1. Passed 1-8-91.)
141.02 DUTIES.
   It shall be the duty of the Records Commission to establish rules and
regulations for the retention and disposal of records of the City which shall
be used by City department heads or other boards, commissions, or committees to
determine when to retain and dispose of records. When requested, the Records
Commission shall review disposal lists to determine whether or not those
records should be destroyed or retained.
(Ord. 2020-112. Passed 11-24-20.)
141.03 RECORDS RETENTION DISPOSITION PROGRAM AND RETENTION SCHEDULES.
   Council hereby adopts the records retention disposition program and
retention schedules as recommended by the Records Commission, a copy of which
program and schedules are on file in the office of the Clerk of Council.
(Res. 1996-79. Passed 12-7-96.)
                                                                                      
CHAPTER 153
Civil Service Commission
153.01    Membership and selection.
153.02    Powers and duties.
153.03    Jurisdiction.
153.04    Classified service.
153.05    Unclassified service.
153.06    Council; City Manager.
153.07    Venue of appeal of decisions of the Civil Service Commission.
CROSS REFERENCES
         Civil service - see CHTR. Art.
VIII
         State law provisions - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 124
153.01 MEMBERSHIP AND SELECTION.
   The Civil Service Commission shall be composed of three members, who shall
be appointed by the Council, but shall not be Council members, and shall serve
in the manner provided in Section
 8.01 of the City Charter.
   It shall be the duty of each member of the Commission to attend all meetings
of the Civil Service Commission and to devote as much time as is necessary to
the management of the business and affairs of the Commission.
   Following the seating of a new City Council, the Commission shall elect in
January of each year one of its members as a chairperson, one as vice-
chairperson and one as secretary. These members shall serve in these positions
until new members are appointed or until the reappointment of old members.
(Ord. 2010-50. Passed 8-24-10.)
153.02 POWERS AND DUTIES.
   The Civil Service Commission shall supervise and approve the holding of
examinations, the content and form of the examinations, the certification of
the eligibles, the keeping of records, and the preparation of regulations
prescribed in a detailed procedure to be followed in the administration of
these rules.
   The Commission shall have the power and shall be required to:
   (a)   Provide civil service rules for determining merit and fitness for
employment and promotion in the classified service; and
   (b)   Hear appeals and render decisions on appeals; and
   (c)   Perform such other duties with reference to personnel administration
relating to the classified service as may be necessary and proper and
consistent with the City Charter and this chapter.
      (Ord. 2010-50. Passed 8-24-10.)
153.03  JURISDICTION.
   The jurisdiction of the Civil Service Commission shall be to determine the
merit and fitness for employment and promotion in the classified service, and
such other matters related to classified employment service as may be necessary
and proper pursuant to the City Charter only for employees of the City.
(Ord. 2010-50. Passed 8-24-10.)
153.04 CLASSIFIED SERVICE.
   The “classified service” consists of the competitive classified civil
service of the City comprised of all positions in the service of the City and
all those positions not specifically included in the unclassified service.
(Ord. 2010-50. Passed 8-24-10.)
153.05 UNCLASSIFIED SERVICE.
   The “unclassified service” consists of those offices and positions of trust
or employment that are exempt from any civil service provisions, including:
   (a)   Elected officials; and members of the City’s boards and commissions;
      (Ord. 2010-50. Passed 8-24-10.)
   (b)    City Manager, Clerk of Council, Director of Finance and Assistant
City Manager;
      (Ord. 2014-125. Passed 12-16-14.)
   (c)   The City Manager’s staff, including the Executive Assistant to the
City Manager, the Clerk of the Mayor’s Court, the directors of all departments,
the division heads within those departments, Deputy Public Works Director,
Department Directors’ Secretaries, the Chief of Police, Police Captain, the
Fire Chief, the City Civil Engineer, and the Assistant Finance Director.
(Ord. 2015-12. Passed 2-24-15.)
   (d)   All unskilled laborers, part-time employees, seasonal employees and
temporary employees;
   (e)   Employees of exceptional professional or scientific qualifications
engaged as consultants for special work by the City;
   (f)   Persons appointed to fill vacancies in elective offices.
   Offices and positions designated above as being in the “unclassified
service” shall be subject to amendment and amended as set forth in the then
current annual City Wages and Classification Ordinance.
(Ord. 2010-50. Passed 8-24-10.)
153.06 COUNCIL; CITY MANAGER.
   Nothing contained herein, or in the rules and regulations of the Civil
Service Commission shall abrogate the powers and duties of Council or the City
Manager as set forth in the Charter.
(Ord. 2010-50. Passed 8-24-10.)
153.07 VENUE OF APPEAL OF DECISIONS OF THE CIVIL SERVICE COMMISSION.
   Any appeal of a decision of the Civil Service Commission that may be taken
under the ordinances of the City, the rules and regulations of the Civil
Service Commission, or the laws of the State of Ohio shall be brought in the
Court of Common Pleas of Clermont County.
(Ord. 2010-50. Passed 8-24-10.)

153
155.01 APPLICATION.
   The following provisions are hereby adopted and enacted and shall be
effective as of January 1, 2012 with reference to fringe benefits, working
conditions and other special provisions for non-union employees of the City of
Loveland.
(Ord. 2011-80. Passed 10-11-11.)
155.02 DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter, certain terms are defined as follows unless the
context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning:
   (a)   "Full-time employee" means an employee appointed by the City Manager
who works a minimum of forty hours per week, twelve months a year.
   (b)   "Part-time employee" means an employee appointed by the City Manager
who works fewer than eight (8) hours a day or fewer than forty (40) hours per
week.
   (c)   "Seasonal employee" means an employee appointed by the City Manager
who works for seven (7) or fewer months within a twelve-month period.
      (Ord. 2011-80. Passed 10-11-11.)
155.03 WORK HOURS; OVERTIME.
   (a)   Work Hours. The regular work week for full-time employees shall be 40
hours per week. Part-time and seasonal employees shall work such hours as
deemed appropriate by their supervisor.
   (b)   Overtime.  All overtime must be authorized by the City Manager or the
City Manager's designee. Authorized work over forty hours per week for FLSA
non-exempt employees shall be computed at one and one-half (1.5) timesthe
employee's regular rate of pay.
   When an FLSA non-exempt employee is required to return to work for an
emergency or other unscheduled reason, he/she will be paid a minimum of three
(3) overtime hours regardless of the duration of the time worked.
(Ord. 2011-80. Passed 10-11-11.)
155.04 VACATIONS.
   All full-time permanent employees shall receive annual paid vacation in
accordance with the following schedule:
Length of Service Hours of Paid Vacation
Partial Year      Prorated based on pay periods worked
1 - 4 years       80 hours
5 - 9 years       120 hours
10 - 14 years     140 hours
15 years          160 hours
16 years          168 hours
17 years          176 hours
18 years          184 hours
19 years          192 hours
20+ years         210 hours
 
   Vacation will be scheduled subject to the approval of the employee’s
supervisor based on workload requirements. Employees may carry over a maximum
of one year vacation hours plus fifty hours to the succeeding year, and the
City Manager shall have the authority to provide for the payout of accumulated
vacation leave in excess of the carryover limit to compensate employees for
extraordinary services rendered to the City.
(Ord. 2017-47. Passed 5-9-17.)
155.05 SICK LEAVE.
   (a)   An employee shall be required to furnish a certificate from a
physician, dentist or other licensed medical practitioner who is treating the
employee, when the employee is absent for three (3) or more consecutive shifts
which he or she is scheduled to work, unless the City Manager grants an
exemption. The City Manager, department head, or Human Resources Manager may
require any employee to provide a certificate from a medical provider under
this section for absences of less than three (3) days where he or she deems it
necessary to verify the proper use of sick leave.
   (b)   Sick leave is credited for full-time employees at 120 hours per year
according to administrative policy and shall be granted as follows for:
      (1)   Illness or injury to the employee.
      (2)   Up to a maximum of five (5) working days, for each illness or
injury, when the illness or injury is to a member of the employee's immediate
family, for whom the employee's care and presence is required.
      (3)   Death of a member of the employee's immediate family. Sick leave
may be used to a maximum of three (3) days. Immediate family is defined as:
spouse, child, mother, father, brother, sister, mother-in-law, father-in-law,
brother-in-law, sister-in-law, grandmother, grandfather or grandchild; and any
aunt, uncle, nephew, niece, or other in-law who was, at the time of their
death, a permanent resident of the employee's household. In the case of the
death of a spouse, child, or parent, the employee may use up to a maximum of
five (5) days of sick leave.
      (4)   Death of any other relative, not defined as a member of the
employee's immediate family (including the death of a close personal friend of
the employee). Sick leave may be used to a maximum of one (1) day, unless the
employee requests and receives their supervisor's advanced approval for
additional time off.
      (5)   Medical, dental or optical examinations or treatment of the
employee, or a member of the employee's immediate family which requires the
presence of the employee.
      (6)   Exposure of the employee to a contagious disease when such
exposure, in the opinion of a licensed physician, would render the employee a
hazard to the health of others, or would further jeopardize the employee's
health or well-being.
   (c)   An employee who retires from City service, except those terminated for
cause or whose resignation was accepted in lieu of being terminated for cause,
with fifteen (15) years service who has accumulated a minimum of four hundred
eighty (480) hours of sick leave, may convert and be paid for fifty percent
(50%) of accrued sick leave. No more than one thousand two hundred and forty-
eight (1,248) hours may be converted, and the maximum converted value may not
exceed six hundred twenty-four (624) hours of pay. In order to be eligible for
the conversion of sick leave, the employee must retire at the time of
separation under one of the public employee retirement systems established by
the State of Ohio or the City of Cincinnati. Notwithstanding the foregoing, an
employee who leaves City service and is entitled to transfer accrued sick leave
to another employer pursuant to Ohio R.C. 124.38, shall notify the City Manager
or the City Manager's designee thereof and such sick leave shall be transferred
and not converted.
   (d)   In the event of the death of an employee other than a death resulting
from the performance of his or her job duties, the employee's accumulated sick
leave shall be converted for payment at fifty percent (50%) of accrued credit.
No more than one thousand two hundred and forty-eight (1,248) hours may be
converted, and the maximum converted value shall therefore not exceed six
hundred and twenty-four (624) hours of pay.
   (e)   If an employee dies as a result of performance of his or her work
duties, one hundred percent (100%) of the employee's accumulated sick leave
shall be converted for payment up to a maximum of one thousand two hundred and
forty-eight (1,248) hours.
(Ord. 2011-80. Passed 10-11-11.)
155.06 HOLIDAYS.
   Full-time employees, after completing six months' probationary employment,
will be entitled to all federally recognized holidays, with the exception of
Washington’s Birthday (Presidents Day) and Columbus Day. Washington’s Birthday
(President’s Day) shall be replaced by Good Friday, and Columbus Day shall be
replaced by the day after Thanksgiving. In addition, full-time employees
receive three floating holidays, to be treated as vacation, at the discretion
of the employee with approval of his/her supervisor. If a holiday falls on a
Saturday, the preceding Friday will be observed as the day off. If a holiday
falls on a Sunday, the following Monday will be observed as the day off. An
employee required by the city to work on a nondiscretionary holiday shall be
paid his or her regular rate of pay plus time and one-half.
(Ord. 2022-64. Passed 7-12-22.)
155.07 MEDICAL INSURANCE COVERAGE.
   (a)   All full time employees whose classification is articulated in the
then-current Wages and Classifications Ordinance shall be eligible for
hospitalization and medical insurance. The City shall pay eighty-five percent
(85%) of the premium starting January 1, 2012 and thereafter for all full-time
employees. City Council Members shall be prohibited in participating and
receiving coverage.
   (b)   (1)   All employees eligible for medical insurance pursuant to Section
155.07(a) who are covered by another health insurance plan who elect not to
participate in the City’s medical insurance plan shall be eligible to receive
reimbursement of one thousand dollars ($1,000) annually based on their status
during the open enrollment period. Those employees electing not to participate
in the City’s health insurance plan shall furnish proof to the City Manager or
the City Manager’s designee of other health insurance prior to receiving
reimbursement. Employees hired during an insurance year who elect to waive City
coverage shall have said reimbursement prorated.   
      (2)   Should an employee have a qualifying event during an insurance year
and subsequently elects to participate in the City’s health insurance plan, the
employee shall be responsible for reimbursing the City of Loveland on a pro-
rated basis for the previously paid incentive attributable to the same plan
year.
   (c)   Permanent part-time employees hired prior to March 28, 2017, covered
under the then-current Wages and Classification Ordinance who work between 500
and 1,560 hours per year will be offered our health insurance, but required to
pay 50% of the premium unless under applicable Federal health insurance law,
that employee is considered to be fulltime, in which case the premiums will be
identical to all other fulltime employees.
   (d)   An employee whose spouse is presently covered or is eligible for
coverage by hospitalization and medical insurance from any other source, other
than insurance for which the employee or spouse must pay more than 50% of the
cost, is not eligible for coverage of the spouse under City hospitalization and
medical insurance policies. For purposes of this section, the cost shall be
calculated based on the cost of the premium for single coverage of the spouse.
If that spouse ceases to be covered, for reasons other than a voluntary waiver
of that coverage or eligibility for coverage, the employee becomes eligible for
coverage of the spouse under the terms and conditions applicable to other City
employees. The spouse shall be covered under the City’s insurance coverage as
soon as possible after the City is notified of the loss of coverage. It is the
duty of the employee to notify the City of any loss of coverage.
(Ord. 2017-28. Passed 3-28-17.)
155.08 (RESERVED FOR FUTURE LEGISLATION.)
155.09 LIFE INSURANCE COVERAGE.
   Each full-time employee and part-time employee working 500 hours or more per
year shall be eligible for a group life insurance policy in an amount equal to
three (3) times their base annual salary, subject to policy reduction formulas
at age 65. For the purpose of determining the amount of such coverage, the base
annual salary shall be that salary which is in effect on July 1 of each year.
(Ord. 2011-80. Passed 10-11-11.)
155.10  LONGEVITY AND IRS 105 AND 125 PROGRAMS.
   (a)   Full-time employees shall be awarded annual longevity pay upon
completion of the following period of employment through the end of 2011.

   And after 2022, this supplemental pay shall be discontinued. Any portion of
longevity pay due to an employee who is eligible to participate in the City of
Loveland Cafeteria Plan (the "Cafeteria Plan") may be designated as a
contribution in to the Plan.
   (b)   For 2012 only, up to forty (40) hours of vacation or compensable leave
time only may be converted into cash.
   (c)   Medical reimbursement and dependent care reimbursement will be paid
monthly upon submission of properly documented expenses according to City
administrative policy. Eligible medical and dependent care expenses are those
allowed by the I.R.S. as described in the City of Loveland Cafeteria Plan
Summary Plan Description.
   (d)   Before the first day of each year, the employee must irrevocably
notify the Finance Director in writing how much of his or her longevity pay,
compensable leave time and/or other compensation shall be contributed to the
Cafeteria Plan or otherwise converted to cash for the coming year.
Contributions to the Cafeteria Plan must be used in the coming year as fully
described in the City of Loveland Cafeteria Plan Summary Plan Description.
(Ord. 2011-80. Passed 10-11-11.)
155.11 (RESERVED FOR FUTURE LEGISLATION.)
155.12 OTHER PROVISIONS.
   (a)   Employees may accumulate up to a maximum of eighty (80) hours
compensatory time for any overtime, to be treated as vacation. If an employee
separates from employment, however, the compensatory time off accrued but not
used must be paid at the employee's regular rate of pay at the time of
separation, or the average of the employee's regular rate of pay over the last
three years, whichever is greater.
   (b)   The City Manager shall have the authority to modify the benefits under
Sections
155.04 and
155.10 so that additional years of seniority may be granted for newly hired
employees with exceptional professional qualifications.
   (c)   Any City employee required by the City to use their own vehicle for
official City business shall be compensated at the mileage rate set by
administrative policy, unless the City employee receives a monthly vehicle
stipend, in which case said mileage reimbursement shall be pursuant to
administrative policy.
   (d)   The City will provide at no cost to Public Works employees summer and
winter uniforms, shoes, coveralls and summer and winter caps as needed.
   (e)   The City shall reimburse one hundred percent (100%) for work-related
damage to or loss of glasses and dental appliances; damage to or loss of
watches, wedding rings or other personal items which occurs in the line of duty
and which is not otherwise compensated for by Workers' Compensation, court
order or other source.
   (f)   Employees may elect to fund an I.R.A. or any other approved deferred
compensation plan with wages.
   (g)   O.P.E.R.S. employee contribution pick-up in accordance with Ordinance
1990-20.
   (h)   Unclassified employees who are "exempt employees" for purposes of FLSA
shall not be credited with compensatory time pursuant to Section
155.12(a) for hours worked over eight hours in a day or 40 hours in a work
week, but shall be afforded reasonable flexibility in scheduling future work
hours to recognize such additional hours worked. Such flex time shall be
documented and shown on the nonclassified, exempt employee's pay records, and
no employee shall be allowed to carry forward more than 80 hours of flex time
unless approved in writing by the City Manager and such time must be used in
the carry over year.
(Ord. 2011-80. Passed 10-11-11.)
155.13 PAYROLL PERIOD.
   The biweekly payroll period shall be established by the City Manager and
shall begin at 5:00 p.m. on the selected day and end at 5:00 p.m. at the end of
the payroll period. Time sheets shall be submitted to the City Manager for
approval at the close of business at the end of the payroll period.
(Ord. 2011-80. Passed 10-11-11.)
155.14 WAGES.
   (a)   Position wage ceilings and adjustments for inflation are established
by City ordinance. Starting wages will be determined by the City Manager based
on the experience, educational background and pertinent special capabilities of
the individual. Wage increases shall be determined by the City Manager through
periodic employee evaluation procedures.
   (b)   To be eligible for an increase in pay, the employee must have received
at least a satisfactory rating on the most recent performance evaluation.
   (c)   If a wage increase is denied because of unsatisfactory performance,
the employee will not be eligible to receive an increase until the following
performance evaluation. A remedial action plan shall be put in place in
accordance with personnel policies. If a satisfactory performance rating is not
achieved in the following performance evaluation, the employee may be
terminated.
(Ord. 2011-80. Passed 10-11-11.)
155.15 RETIREMENT SYSTEM; PICK-UP PLAN FOR ELECTED OFFICIALS AND EMPLOYEES.
   (a)   Effective April 5, 1990, the full amount of the statutorily required
contribution to the Ohio Public Employees Retirement System shall be withheld
from the gross pay of each City elected official and of each person who is an
employee of the City who is a member of the Ohio Public Employees Retirement
System and shall be "picked up" (assumed and paid to the Ohio Public Employees
Retirement System) by the City. This "pick up" by the City is and shall be
designated as public employee contributions and shall be in lieu of
contributions to the Ohio Public Employees Retirement System by each such
person. No person subject to this "pick up" shall have the option of choosing
to receive the statutorily required contribution to the Ohio Public Employees
Retirement System instead of having it "picked up" by the City.
   (b)   The City through its proper officers shall, in reporting and making
remittance to the Ohio Public Employees Retirement System, report that the
public employee's contribution for each person subject to their "pick up" has
been made by the City of Loveland in lieu of contributions to said Ohio Public
Employees Retirement System by each such person and that such contributions are
designated as public employee contributions.
(Ord. 2011-80. Passed 10-11-11.)
155.16  SEVERANCE.
   Upon separation from employment for any reason, an employee shall receive
compensation for all hours worked or credited but unpaid, and any unused
vacation credit, but shall not be compensated for unused flextime. Computation
shall be at the rate of pay in effect on the employee's last date of work
except that compensation for accrued but unused compensatory time off must be
at the employee's regular rate at the time of separation, or the average of the
regular rate over the final three years of the employee's service, whichever is
provided, as provided in the FLSA. Such payment, at the employee's discretion,
may be deferred for up to one year after the employee's departure from City
service. In the event of an employee's death, such payment shall be made
directly to the employee's beneficiary, or estate if no beneficiary is named.
(Ord. 2011-80. Passed 10-11-11.
155.17 (RESERVED FOR FUTURE LEGISLATION.)
155.18 PUBLIC OFFICIAL LIABILITY INSURANCE DEDUCTIBLE PROVISION.
   Council does hereby declare its intent and establishes the policy that in
the event a public official is charged under the deductible provision of the
public official liability insurance policy, the expense shall be paid from
funds appropriated to the General Fund only to the extent specified in the
deductible provision of the City insurance coverage.
(Ord. 2011-80. Passed 10-11-11.)
155.19 RELOCATION BENEFIT.
   Employees other than the City Manager are not required to reside within the
City limits, but the City of Loveland encourages all employees to consider
residing inside the City limits. Pursuant to the City's policies, the City
Manager may offer any current or new employees a five thousand dollar ($5,000)
relocation benefit if they purchase and reside in a home inside the corporate
limits of the City of Loveland, pursuant to the City's written policy. An
employee who elects to rent a property in the corporate limits of the City of
Loveland and to use such property for his or her primary residence may receive
a one thousand dollar ($1,000) relocation benefit pursuant to the City's
written policy.
(Ord. 2011-80. Passed 10-11-11.)
155.20 LOVELAND-BASED CHARITABLE DONATIONS.
   Employees may voluntarily donate through payroll deductions to Qualified
Charitable Organizations under 170(c) of the Internal Revenue Code
headquartered within the corporate limits of the City of Loveland, including,
but not limited to: the Loveland Stage Company, Loveland Inter Faith Effort
(L.I.F.E.), the Loveland Initiative, the Greater Loveland Historical Society
and Museum, Loveland Firefighters Association, Fraternal Order of Eagles 3006,
the Loveland Chapter of the American Legion, the Loveland Chapter of the VFW,
the Loveland Athletic Boosters, and the Loveland Chapter of the Moose.
(Ord. 2011-80. Passed 10-11-11.)
155.21 PAGER PAY.
   Non-exempt employees of the Department of Public Works who carry the street
pager are to be compensated for an additional 128 hours per 7 day work week at
the rate of seventy-five cents ($0.75) per hour for hours on call other than
their normally scheduled 40 work week hours, or ninety-six dollars ($96.00) per
week. The person carrying the street pager shall be responsible for responding
to call outs for all non-water related public works emergency matters. The
person carrying the street pager shall be designated in advance each week by
the Director of Public Works.
(Ord. 2011-80. Passed 10-11-11.)
CHAPTER 157
Emergency Disaster Powers
157.01   Purpose.
157.02   Definitions.
157.03   Powers and duties of the City Manager.
157.04   Effect of chapter.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Emergency management - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 5915
Misconduct in an emergency - see GEN. OFF.
509.05
 
 
157.01 PURPOSE.
   To define, outline, and authorize the powers and duties of the City Manager
or his or her designee in the event of a disaster or emergency.
(Ord. 2006-28. Passed 4-11-06.)
157.02 DEFINITIONS.
   (a)   “City Manager” shall mean the City Manager of the City of Loveland, or
in the event of the City Manager’s absence, the administrative employee
designated by the City Manager to act as the City Manager as set forth in
Section
4.03 of the Charter.
   (b)   “City of Loveland emergency operations plan” shall mean the plan of
operations developed by City officials to manage emergency or disaster
situations as approved by the City Manager.
   (c)   “Disaster” shall mean any natural or man-made calamity, which
threatens or causes the loss of life and property and exceeds the routine
capabilities of local government, including the City, health care, and
community agencies, including, but not limited to, flood, major fire, tornado,
severe storm, earthquake, hazardous material incidents, or explosion.
   (d)   “Emergency” shall mean any clear or present danger to the health,
safety, welfare or property of the residents of the City, including, but not
limited to civil disturbance, riot, foreign or domestic terrorist attacks, or
any event or occurrence that substantially impairs the effective functioning of
the City’s government and the City’s ability to provide essential services and
protect the lives and property of the residents of the City.
(Ord. 2006-28. Passed 4-11-06.)
157.03 POWERS AND DUTIES OF THE CITY MANAGER.
   In addition to other powers and duties under this Code and the Charter, the
City Manager shall have the following powers and duties relating to emergencies
and disasters:
   (a)   Maintain an approved City of Loveland emergency operations plan that
shall be reviewed and approved annually by the City Manager.
   (b)   (1)   Upon the determination by the City Manager after consultation
with the Police Department and the Loveland Symmes Fire Department, declare an
emergency or disaster. Such declaration shall not extend for a period in excess
of thirty days without the approval of Council. The City Manager shall notify
Council of a declaration of an emergency or disaster as soon as possible.
      (2)   City Council shall convene within fifteen days of a declaration of
an emergency or disaster.
   (c)   In the event of an emergency or disaster, the City Manager is further
authorized to take any or all of the following actions:
      (1)   Implement and oversee the City of Loveland emergency operations
plan.
      (2)   Issue emergency orders to control and maintain the public peace,
health, safety and welfare within the City including, but not limited to:
         A.   Orders to control or restrict traffic within the City.
         B.   Orders to restrict access to the City.
         C.   Orders to enforce curfews or other necessary measures.
      (3)   Notify County, State and Federal Governments and agencies of the
declaration of an emergency or disaster.
      (4)   Contract with County, State and Federal Governments and agencies
for additional services and to provide disaster assistance and relief to
residents of the City during the course of an emergency or disaster.
      (5)   Enter into contracts without advertising and bidding and without
the prior approval of Council, such approval and authorization deemed to have
been granted by this section, for such services or equipment as may be
necessary to secure or repair public or private property within the City. This
authorization shall not extend for a period in excess of thirty days from the
date of declaration of an emergency or disaster without the approval of
Council. This authorization shall not exceed the amount of available funds in
the city contingency fund plus an additional one hundred fifty thousand dollars
($150,000). The City Manager shall provide an accounting of expenditures to
Council within sixty days of the declaration of an emergency or disaster.
      (6)   Take any other action necessary to assure the public health, safety
and welfare, and property of the residents of the City and maintain essential
service to City residents.
         (Ord. 2006-28. Passed 4-11-06.)
157.04 EFFECT OF CHAPTER.
   This chapter shall not affect any other power or duty of the City Manager as
set forth in the Code or the Charter. (Ord. 2006-28. Passed 4-11-06.)
                                                                                                                             
CHAPTER 159
Debt Assessment
159.01   Assessment to become lien.
159.02       Administrative fee for property maintenance and zoning code
compliance.
159.03       Calculating and charging administrative fees in excess of the set
administrative fees set forth in Section
159.02 .
159.04       Billing procedures.
 
 
159.01 ASSESSMENT TO BECOME LIEN.
   Any debt or bill due and owing the City for which no other means of
assessment against real property is provided in the Codified Ordinances shall
be assessed and collected pursuant to this section when any such debts or bills
have not been paid within a sixty-day period of time from the due date thereof.
Such unpaid debts or bills shall be reported yearly to Council by the Finance
Director and Council shall certify such debt or bill, along with penalties, to
the County Auditor of the County where the lands to which the service has been
provided are located who shall place the assessment on the tax duplicate of
their county. Such assessment shall then become a lien upon such lands from the
date of such notice to the County Auditor, and shall be collected by the County
Auditor as other taxes, and returned to the City.
(Ord. 2006-62. Passed 8-22-06.)
159.02 ADMINISTRATIVE FEE FOR PROPERTY MAINTENANCE AND ZONING CODE COMPLIANCE.
   Council hereby establishes a set administrative fee, which fee shall be
added to the actual cost the City incurs in abating or causing to be abated
each Property Maintenance and Zoning Code violations. The set administrative
fee shall be established by ordinance of City Council, and shall be added to
the costs incurred to address each violation of the Property Maintenance and
Zoning Code if not paid by the property owner shall be added to the property
tax assessment at the same time City Council passes an ordinance authorizing a
property tax assessment.
(Ord. 2016-96. Passed 12-6-16.)
159.03 CALCULATING AND CHARGING ADMINISTRATIVE FEES IN EXCESS OF THE SET
ADMINISTRATIVE FEES SET FORTH IN SECTION
159.02.
   In the event that the set administrative fee established pursuant to Section
159.02 does not adequately recover administrative costs incurred by the City in
abating or causing to be abated Property Maintenance Code violations, the City
shall be entitled to charge additional sums as administrative fees to
compensate the City for its actual time and expenses incurred in enforcing its
Property Maintenance Code. Such additional administrative fees shall be
established by ordinance of City Council.
(Ord. 2009-56. Passed 9-22-09.)
159.04 BILLING PROCEDURES.
   All administrative fees to be charged pursuant to Sections
159.02 and
159.03 above shall be billed by the City to the property owner or those
responsible for paying for property maintenance along with the bill for the
cost of services provided by the City for property maintenance.
(Ord. 2009-56. Passed 9-22-09.)
                                                                                                                            
TITLE SEVEN - Judicial

CHAPTER 171
Mayor’s Court
171.01   Judicial functions vested in magistrate.
171.02   Unofficial Juvenile Court.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Mayor’s Court - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 1905
 
 
171.01 JUDICIAL FUNCTIONS VESTED IN MAGISTRATE.
   The judicial functions of the City, as set forth in Ohio R.C. 1905.05, shall
be vested in and performed by a magistrate. The magistrate shall be an attorney
at law meeting the requirements of the above referenced section and shall be
knowledgeable in Ohio criminal law and procedure. The magistrate shall be
appointed by the Mayor for an indefinite term of office with the approval of
Council.
(Ord. 1992-54. Passed 8-11-92.)
171.02 UNOFFICIAL JUVENILE COURT.
   (a)   Council hereby approves of the establishment of an Unofficial Juvenile
Court.
   (b)   This Unofficial Juvenile Court shall dispose of cases involving
misdemeanor offenses committed by nonhabitual offenders under the age of
eighteen within the City which are referred to the Unofficial Juvenile Referee
by the Police Department of the City.
   (c)   The City Manager is hereby authorized to take such action as is
necessary for the establishment of the said Unofficial Juvenile Court including
entering into any agreements with Hamilton, Clermont and Warren County
officials, attending to the appointment of an Unofficial Juvenile Referee,
establishing a Juvenile Intervention Unit within the Police Department of the
City, and, in conjunction with the City Law Department, promulgating such rules
and regulations as are necessary to carry the said Unofficial Juvenile Court
program into effect.
(Ord. 1997-4. Passed 1-14-97.)

CHAPTER 183
Income Tax
EDITOR’S NOTE: Pursuant to Ordinance 2009-47, passed July 28, 2009, the City

VI
